messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Genes are small parts in our body.  
They tell our body how to grow and work.  
Language is how people speak and write to share ideas.  
Scientists study if gene changes helped us talk.  
They found a gene change long ago.  
It happened 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.  
It helps our brain control mouth and face when we speak.  
Monkeys have the same gene.  
But their gene did not change.  
We do not know if genes help talk a lot.  
DNA is a code in our body.  
Maybe one day we find the answer in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6706 is below the required 0.75. FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8676 is below the required 0.90.
- The text omits the key phrase “influence of genetics on brain and language development” and reduces it to “genes are small parts in our body,” losing the core scientific focus.
- The question “Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability?” is removed, erasing the original inquiry.
- The technical term “mutation” is replaced with the vague word “change,” diluting precision.
- The definitions of “language” and “DNA” are added but distract from the original research details.
- The exact wording “mutation that occurred between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago” is fragmented, hurting fidelity.
Suggestion: Restore the term “mutation.” Reintroduce the research question about genes and language. Keep the full phrase “influence of genetics on brain and language development.” Use the precise time frame in one sentence. Remove unrelated definitions to focus on the scientific message and improve lexical overlap.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Genes are small parts in our body.  
They tell our body how to grow.  
Language is how people speak and write.  
People ask about the influence of genetics on brain and language development.  
Are there genes that mutated and gave us language ability?  
Researchers found a mutation between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago.  
This mutation helps our brain control our mouth.  
It also helps control our face when we speak.  
Monkeys have the same gene.  
But their gene did not have this mutation.  
We do not know how much genes help language.  
Maybe one day we find the answer in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8926 is below the required 0.90, indicating significant loss of lexical detail. Deviations:
- The text introduces two new definition sentences about genes and language not in the original, reducing overlap.
- The phrase "have a connection with" was replaced by "helps", losing the nuance of research uncertainty.
- "help our brain control our mouth" and "help control our face" simplify "how our brains control our mouths and face", altering phrasing and reducing exact overlap.
- "one day the answers might be found" changed to "maybe one day we find the answer", modifying modality and number.
Suggestion: Remove the added definitions, restore key original phrases like "have a connection with", keep "answers" plural, and use the exact wording for "how our brains control our mouths and face" to improve BERTScore.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: People ask how genes help the brain and language grow.  
Are there genes that changed and gave us language ability?  
Researchers found a gene mutation between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago.  
It seems to have a connection with speaking.  
It seems to have a connection with how our brains control mouths.  
It seems to have a connection with how our brains control face.  
Monkeys have the same gene, but it did not have this mutation.  
We do not know how much genes help language.  
One day the answers might be found in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Factual Inaccuracy. The Writer's Output states "Monkeys have the same gene" but the Original Text says "Monkeys have a similar gene".

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Genes are parts of cells. They carry information.
Language is the words we speak or write.
People ask how genes help the brain and language grow.
Are there genes that changed and gave us language ability?
Researchers found a gene change 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.
It seems to help us speak and move our mouth and face.
Monkeys have a similar gene, but it did not change.
We do not know how much genes help language.
One day we might find the answers in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 5/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance Failure. The text uses several words above the A2 level.
- The word "genes"/"gene" is B2 level and must be replaced with a simple phrase like "parts that carry information in our body."  
- "DNA" is a technical term not on the A2 list. Replace it with "the code in our cells" or "the body code."  
- "Researchers" is advanced. Change to "people who study cells and genes."  
- "cells" is a B2 term. Use "tiny parts in our body."  
Suggestion: Replace each B2 word with a simple A2-friendly phrase. Make sure no technical or multi-syllable terms remain.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Parts that carry information in our body are called genes.  
Language is the words we speak or write.  
People ask how they help the brain and language grow.  
Some people think they changed and gave us language ability.  
People who study tiny parts in our body found a change.  
It was 200,000 to 100,000 years ago.  
The change helps us speak.  
It also helps us move our mouth and face.  
Monkeys have the same parts, but they did not change.  
We do not know how much they help language.  
One day we might find the answers in the body code.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development.  
Are there genes that changed and gave us language ability?  
Researchers found a change in a gene between 200,000 and 100,000 years ago.  
This change seems to have a connection with speaking.  
It seems to have a connection with how our brain controls our mouth and face.  
Monkeys have a similar gene, but they did not have this change.  
We do not know how much influence genetics have on language.  
One day we might find the answers in our DNA.
Feedback received: Grade 5/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance. The text uses words and structures above A2 level.
Detected deviations:
- influence (B1 word)
- development (B1 word)
- genetics (not in A2 list, B2-level)
- connection (B1 word)
- complex sentence structure in sentence 1: “More questions lie in looking at the influence of genetics on brain and language development.” uses the phrase “lie in looking at” and multiple prepositional phrases.
- repeated separate sentences that still contain B1 vocabulary and complex noun phrases.
Corrective path:
Replace influence with "effect" or "how genes change"
Replace development with "growth"
Replace genetics with "genes"
Replace connection with "link"
Split long sentences into short ones (subject + verb + object).
Use only A2-approved words and connectors: and, but, so, because.

Monkeys have a similar gene.  
But they do not have this mutation.
